text: A few things: "white" minority ethnic groups most certainly did live in ancient and Imperial China. They're called the Tocharians, the Wusun, the Yuezhi, the Sogdians, and the Cumans, all of them Indo-Europeans with similar languages except for the Cumans, who spoke a Turkic language (many Cumans were also Asiatic instead of Caucasian). Then we have foreigners who came later: Persians (bringing Manichaeanism, Zoroastrianism, and Islam) and West Asian Semites (bringing Nestorian Christianity, Judaism, and Islam) arriving in the 7th century, Italian merchants and their families (bringing Catholocism) arriving in the 13th century, mostly from Genoa and Venice, Papal diplomats and missionaries from Rome, Portuguese, and Spaniards (bringing Catholocism) arriving in the 16th century as explorers, traders and conquerors, and finally Dutchmen and Englishmen (bringing Protestant creeds to the southern shores of China). White people living in China today include the Pamiri Tajiks, descendants of those ancient Sogdians who were so numerous in China during the Tang period, and the Macanese of Macau (the latter mostly being mixed race, though).  So now that we've established that there were native white people in historical Imperial China who considered it their home, let's bring up the fact that Matt Damon and Pedro Pascal are supposedly playing medieval Western European mercenaries. That's a far-fetched idea, since the only Europeans in Song and Yuan era China were merchants, missionaries, and diplomats as described above. Yet this is a fantasy movie about dragon slug monsters, so historical realism doesn't matter. This is a historical fantasy, not a standard historical drama, so having white Westerners in the cast is absolutely fine. It's also hardly whitewashing, since they aren't stealing Chinese roles. This is a film directed by Zhang Yimou and produced in China by Chinese production companies. Chinese moviegoing audiences welcome the presence of Western actors because in their view this promotes diversity in their own films, which are overbearingly Han Chinese. It would be nice if more of the 56 official ethnic monorities of China got more screen time, but this is just as good in my opinion. In China white people are in fact "people of color" compared to the Han Chinese ethnic majority.

text: Aside from his solid stardom appeal to a Western audience, I think you're missing the major plot point as to why Matt Damon is in this film. Nevermind the fact that white Indo-European ethnic minorities existed in ancient and Imperial China (the Tocharians, the Yuezhi, the Wusun, and most especially the Sogdians, their Pamiri Tajik descendants still living in Xinjiang, China to this day), how about the fact that THERE WERE MEDIEVAL EUROPEANS IN IMPERIAL CHINA. This film is set during the Northern Song period (960- 1127 AD). During the Southern Song (1127 - 1279 AD) and Yuan Dynasty, European merchants, mostly Italians from Venice and Genoa, began settling in Yangzhou with their entire families in tow. Papal diplomats and missionaries from Rome continuously made trips back and forth from Western Europe to the Mongol courts at Karakorum in Mongolia, and Dadu in China (modern-day Beijing). Forget Marco Polo, the most famous medieval European in China only because of his well-received book about the matter. William of Rubruck is the man you should focus on. A Flemish Franciscan monk, William arrived at the court of Mongke Khan (then the ruler of the northern half of China, his successor Kublai Khan would finish the conquest of southern China later on) in January of 1254 AD. He is the most likely candidate for learning the Chinese formula for gunpowder and bringing it to Europe, since his friend Roger Bacon, the English philosopher and scientist, was the first man in Europe to record the formula for gunpowder, in 1267 AD.   Matt Damon is essentially going to play the mercenary soldier version of William of Rubruck. William's life certainly wasn't boring and it would make a good movie, albeit not even as popular as Marco Polo on Netflix. Genrerally speaking, people are ignorant and stupid, especially the moviegoing public (sorry guys, it's true, look at all the super hero movies). Let's face it: the only way they could make a movie about this was by adding dragons in it and having Matt Damon bungee jump off the Great Wall while blowing things up with Chinese gunpowder rocket arrows. People would much rather see that then a real historical drama about the man who most likely spread gunpowder from China to Europe in the 13th century. If we pushed this back further in time, Damon could easily play the role of a ancient Roman, seeing how they led embassies to Eastern Han China from 166 AD onwards, or a Byzantine Greek, considering how their monks smuggled silkworms from the Northern Qi Empire of China back to the Eastern Roman Empire during the mid 6th century. Or they could have even set this movie during the much later Ming Dynasty, and had Damon play a Portugueseman, Spaniard, or Italian who arrived on the southern shores of China during the early 16th century. Hell, they could have even made him a Sogdian general like Li Baoyu during the Tang Dynasty, who became the Duke of Liang for his role in suppressing An Lushan's rebellion (wink, wink, yet another white Indo-European Sogdian general) and fighting the Tibetans in the mid 8th century AD.
